customer_name: Laredo Safari and Adventure Park LLC
site_name: Laredo Safari and Adventure Park LLC

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During this inspection the following animals were identified to have medical conditions requiring veterinary care.
• A zebu with a lame right front foot. The animal was holding the foot up while grazing and placing it very carefully when
walking.
• At least 3 simitar horned oryx were extremely thin with body condition scores of about 2 out of 5.
• One thin bison with a body condition score of about 2 out of 5.
• A mongoose with a head tilt
• Several goats in the petting zoo with very long hooves.
The facility representative confirmed that she knew about the zebu and the oryx, however she had not noticed the head
tilt in the mongoose. The attending veterinarian had not been consulted about any of these issues. Not consulting with the
veterinarian in a timely fashion can cause prolonged pain and discomfort for the animals.
The facility needs to ensure daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being is occurring. Daily
observation may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian, provided that mechanism of direct
and frequent communication is required so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior,
and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.
Correct by Dec 8, 2023

Acquisition/birth and disposition/death records are required so that animals being used in regulated activities can be
accurately tracked to ensure their legal acquisition, proper care, and humane transportation. The following records were
not available or complete during this inspection.
Disposition/deaths
• Gemsbok: 3 animals
• Pere David’s deer: 3 animals
• Red lechwe: 8 animals
• Ibex: 2 animals
• Scimitar horned oryx: 13 animals
• Addax: 13 animals
• Barasingha: 1 animal
• Armenian mouflon: 13 animals
• Blackbuck: 2 animals
• Ring-tailed lemur: 1 animal
• Vervet: 1 animal
• Patagonian cavy: 1 animal
• Sika: 3 animals
Acquisitions/births
• Kangaroo: 1 animal
• Baboons: 2 animals
• Serval: 2 animals
• Mongoose: 1 animal
• Macaque: 1 animal
Animals transferred to or acquired from other licensees must have disposition and acquisition records containing all
information required by the Animal Welfare Regulations available during inspections. This requirement applies to all
regulated animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased or otherwise in possession of or under control of
the licensee, and all regulated animals transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by the dealer or exhibitor.
The records shall include any offspring born of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her control.
Correct by Dec 14, 2023

Visitors currently enter the facility by pulling up to an automatic gate, pushing a button that opens the gate, then driving
across a cattle guard and into a pasture with a large assortment of exotic hoofed stock. This pasture is the primary
enclosure for the hoofed stock. After passing through the gate and into the pasture, the public must drive about half a mile
before they reach the visitor center, the petting zoo, and the zip line. None of these areas have barriers that separate the
animals in the pasture from the visitors. Many of these animals can be dangerous if adequately provoked and can cause
serious injury to a person.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of the
animals and the public.
Correct by April 1, 2024

The ring-tailed lemurs are currently housed on an island. They have several elevated wood houses to block wind and rain,
however their heat source is set up in a gutted vehicle. This vehicle is not insulated, and areas were windows and doors
used to be are now covered by wood and metal. The heat is provided by a propane tank with two tank top heaters
positioned on the hood and pointing thru the front windshield. The heaters are surrounded by an old wire cage as
protection, but the lemurs can easily reach in and touch the heaters. This situation is inadequate for the following reasons:
• Fumes from the propane could be dangerous to the animals.
• The lemurs could easily burn themselves on the heaters or the cage surrounding the heaters.
Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the
species. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely,
and restrict other animals from entering.
Correct by Dec 14, 2023

The facility has been allowing visitors to go onto the island with the lemurs and offer them food. According to an incident
report provided by the facility, on November 24, 2023, one of the lemurs jumped onto the back of a five-year-old child to
reach for a banana. Somehow the child was bitten on the arm in the process.
Insufficiently controlled animal encounters can negatively impact both the public and the animals. This contact can result
in stress, disease transmission, injuries or even death to animals and/or visitors. Animals that bite may be subject to
mandatory euthanasia in accordance with local or state public health requirements.
Nonhuman primates used in trained animal acts or in uncaged public exhibits must be under the direct control and
supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times when the public is present. Trained nonhuman primates may
be permitted physical contact with the public, as allowed under § 2.131, but only if they are under the direct control and
supervision of an experienced handler or trainer at all times during the contact.

The pair of olive baboons are being temporarily housed in a converted goat pen. The pen is approximately 15 x 15 x 5
feet tall. There is a roof over most of the enclosure with one side providing protection from wind and rain, one side
providing protection from rain, and two sides without protection from either. There is not additional structure for the
baboons to escape blowing wind and rain.
The macaque is being temporarily housed in a converted goat pen in the interior of an open sided barn. The pen is
approximately 10 x 10 x 8 feet tall. The enclosure provides shelter from rain but does not provide shelter from excessive
wind. There is not an additional structure in the enclosure allowing the macaque to escape wind.
Outdoor housing facilities for nonhuman primates must provide adequate shelter from the elements at all times. It must
provide protection from the sun, rain, snow, wind, and cold, and from any weather conditions that may occur. The shelter
must safely provide heat to the nonhuman primates to prevent the ambient temperature from falling below 45 F.
Correct by Dec 14, 2023

The facility recently acquired two servals and are in the process of building new habitats for the animals. Currently both
cats are being maintained in inadequate enclosures.
One serval is being housed in an approximately 2 x 8 x 6 ft tall wire panel enclosure. The enclosure has a roof consisting
of a piece of plywood and a metal wire panel covered with a tarp laid over the top of the enclosure. Two sides are covered
with either plywood or tarps.
The second serval is being housed in a 4 x 4 x 6 ft tall wire panel enclosure inside a barn. The top of the enclosure is a
piece of plywood laid across the cage but not secured to the cage.
Neither enclosure is structurally sound. The plywood on top of both enclosures is not secured to the cages. The plywood
could blow off or the servals could squeeze under them and escape.
The facility must provide enclosures that are structurally sound and maintained in good repair.
Correct by Dec 14, 2023

Neither serval enclosure is large enough for the cats to make normal postural and social adjustments. Neither enclosure
allows the cats to walk more than a few feet without turning around and re-walking the same path, and neither enclosure
provides an area for the cats to hide from the public if they become stressed.
During this inspection, one of the servals was noted to be pacing back and forth in its enclosure. This is a common sign of
stress in animals and could be caused by the insufficient space.
Enclosures shall be constructed and maintained so as to provide sufficient space to allow each animal to make normal
postural and social adjustments with adequate freedom of movement. Inadequate space may be indicated by evidence of
malnutrition, poor condition, debility, stress, or abnormal behavior patterns.
Correct by Dec 14, 2023

The petting zoo goats are being fed a pelleted diet in feeders on the ground. During this inspection, goats were noted
standing in the feeders. In many of the feeders the pellets were more powder than pellet. Not only does allowing the goats
to stand in the feeders crush the food, but it also allows feces and mud on the goat hooves to contaminate the food.
Food and food receptacles shall be sufficient in quantity and located so as to be accessible to all animals in the enclosure
and shall be placed so as to minimize contamination.
Correct by Dec 8, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
